CountryData.name: Tuvalu
CountryData.description: Tuvalu, known as the ‘Tuvaluan Archipelago,’ is a Polynesian island nation consisting of nine low-lying coral atolls in the Pacific Ocean. It’s the third smallest state in the world and faces significant challenges from rising sea levels and climate change. The nation’s culture is deeply rooted in traditional Polynesian values, with a strong emphasis on community and connection to the ocean.  Its economy relies heavily on fishing and remittances.  Tuvalu is a member of the Commonwealth and has a unique system of governance based on consensus.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: The population of Tuvalu is small and dispersed across its atolls.
quickFacts.detail: The population density is extremely low, making it one of the least densely populated countries in the world.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.description: Tuvalu is a very small island nation.
quickFacts.detail: It comprises nine islands: Funafuti, Nanumea, Niutao, Nui, Nukufetau, Niulkifetau, Niulakita, and Vaitupu.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: Funafuti is the administrative and economic center of Tuvalu.
quickFacts.detail: It’s the only atoll with a proper airport.

quickFacts.label: Official Language
quickFacts.detail: English is also spoken, particularly in government and education.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.detail: It is pegged to the New Zealand Dollar.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.description: Tuvalu's economy is largely dependent on fishing and remittances.
quickFacts.detail: The country is highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change.

climateData.title: Climate of Tuvalu
climateData.description: Tuvalu experiences a tropical maritime climate characterized by consistently high temperatures and humidity throughout the year. Rainfall is abundant, with a distinct wet season from November to April.  The islands are susceptible to cyclones, particularly during the November-April period.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Wet Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: This period is marked by frequent rainfall, high humidity, and a greater risk of cyclones.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Dry Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The dry season brings lower rainfall, reduced humidity, and calmer seas.  Temperatures remain consistently warm.

naturalWonders.name: Funafuti Lagoon
naturalWonders.description: Funafuti Lagoon is a stunning coral atoll lagoon, a vital habitat for a diverse range of marine life. It’s a crucial breeding ground for many fish species and a popular destination for divers and snorkelers.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The lagoon’s shallow, clear waters are teeming with colorful coral reefs, vibrant fish, and sea turtles. It’s a protected area, playing a critical role in the nation’s ecosystem.

naturalWonders.name: Nanumea Atoll
naturalWonders.description: Nanumea Atoll is a remarkably flat and low-lying coral atoll, renowned for its pristine beaches and unique sand formations.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The atoll’s distinctive ‘sand dunes’ are formed by the constant action of waves and winds. It’s a haven for birdlife and offers a tranquil escape.
viewingTips: Take a guided tour of the sand dunes

ecosystemData.title: Ecosystems of Tuvalu
ecosystemData.overview: Tuvalu’s ecosystems are primarily marine, dominated by coral reefs, lagoons, and mangrove forests. The islands themselves are low-lying and vulnerable to erosion and sea-level rise.  The interconnectedness of these ecosystems is vital for the nation’s survival.

biodiversityCategories.name: Marine Biodiversity
biodiversityCategories.description: The marine environment is incredibly rich and diverse, supporting a wide array of fish, coral, and invertebrate species.

statistics.details: A significant portion of the world’s coral species are found in Tuvalu’s reefs.
The lagoon supports commercially important fish species like tuna and mackerel.

notableSpecies.name: Green Turtle
notableSpecies.significance: A key indicator species for the health of the reef ecosystem.

notableSpecies.name: Grey Reef Shark
notableSpecies.significance: An apex predator crucial for maintaining the balance of the marine food web.

biodiversityCategories.name: Coastal Vegetation
biodiversityCategories.description: Mangrove forests and coastal shrubs provide vital habitat and protect the islands from erosion.

statistics.details: Mangroves are crucial for coastal protection and carbon sequestration.

notableSpecies.name: Coconut Palm
notableSpecies.significance: A primary food source and building material for the local population.

activities.title: Activities in Tuvalu
activities.description: Tuvalu offers a range of activities, primarily focused on experiencing the natural beauty of the islands and engaging with local culture.

activityCategories.name: Water Sports
activityCategories.description: Enjoy the crystal-clear waters of Tuvalu’s lagoon.

activities.name: Snorkeling
activities.description: Explore the vibrant coral reefs and diverse marine life.
activities.requirements: Swimsuit, reef-safe sunscreen, mask and snorkel (rental available)

activities.name: Diving
activities.description: Discover the underwater wonders of Tuvalu’s coral reefs.

activities.name: Fishing
activities.requirements: Fishing license (if required), fishing gear (rental available)

activityCategories.name: Cultural Activities
activityCategories.description: Immerse yourself in the rich traditions of Tuvalu.

activities.name: Village Tours
activities.description: Learn about Tuvaluan customs and traditions.
safety: Ask for permission before taking photos

activities.name: Traditional Ceremonies
activities.description: Witness traditional dances, songs, and rituals.

clothing.summer: Lightweight, breathable clothing, swimwear, hat, sunglasses
clothing.yearRound: Modest clothing, covering shoulders and knees when visiting villages

equipment.basic: Sunscreen, insect repellent, water bottle, flashlight
equipment.hiking: Sturdy walking shoes, backpack, map, compass
